author: Catie Low
title: Woolworths chases potential private equity deal
text:
Woolworths may be seeking private equity investment in Big W Glenn Hunt by Catie Low Woolworths is believed to be courting private equity investment in its embattled Big W business and could seek a joint-venture partner to fast-track the transformation of the discount department chain.
Private Equity giant KKR & Co and TPG Capital have both been linked with Big W but sources close to the talks suggest that it is Woolworths, not private equity is driving this process.
Woolworths may be tapping private equity to work up an accurate valuation of Big W before it decides on its future, but insiders believe the embattled retailer is keen to negotiate a joint-venture agreement.
A partnership with private equity could inject funds into the business and put it back in the fight with its biggest competitors Wesfarmers', Target and Kmart, which both reported strong sales increases for the first quarter of fiscal 2016.
Woolworths would not make any comment and neither would KKR or TPG.
Woolworths chair Gordon Cairns promised to return Australia's biggest supermarket to its glory days when he stepped up at the retailer's full-year results in August and there are already signs the new chair is shaking things up.
But there's increasing pressure on him to make a decision on the loss-making Masters hardware business and Big W ahead of the appointment of the new chief.
Former chief Grant O'Brien announced plans to quit the business in June just weeks after unveiling a plan to revitalise the supermarket's food and liquor business by cutting costs by $500 million and pumping those savings back into lowering prices.
 Analysts suggest Woolworths could free up as much as $3 billion in capital if it cut loose Masters and sold off Big W.
Morgan Stanley valued the 184-store Big W business at about $1 billion before the release of its full-year results, which revealed a 25 per cent slide in its operating income to $114.2 million.
Analyst Tom Kierath said the discount department stores played in a "tough" space with competition from online as well as the new international retailers like H&M and now Debenhams, which has struck a deal with Harris Scarfe owner Pepko to launch in Australia.
"You've got Kmart winning at the bottom end of the market and I don't think that space is all that attractive," Mr Kierath said.
He said it was logical for a new chair to look at all the options for the business and private equity may see it as an opportunity to pick up Big W on the cheap.
Based on its performance in 2013, when it reported earnings before interest tax debt and amortisation of about $300 million, Big W could be worth as much as $3 billion according to one analyst.
"It just depends on how you value it," he said.
"Last year it did EBITDA of about $200 million, two years ago it was closer to $300 million.
"So they will not sell it for $1.5 billion and I don't think they are going to sell Big W if a decision has been made to sell Masters."
The Big W business could be worth as much as $3 billion based on its earnings performance from 2013, before it bowed out of hardware.
